summary: Homilies for Sundays and festivals other than Saints' days, from the incomplete initial homily for the second Sunday after Epiphany to Pentecost. Twenty-two homilies are from the First and Second Series of Ã†lfric's Sermones Catholici (ed. Thorpe 1844-46). The collection is similar to, but fuller than CUL Ii. 4. 6 and, most notably, CCCC 302. A number of the anonymous homilies are unique to this manuscript and CCCC 302. There are twelfth-century alterations on fols 119v-30v and 162v-4v (Ker 1957, p. 190).

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (Begins imperfectly) þurh his mihte

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Fol. 1, a supply leaf, contains the missing portion in a hand of the s. xvi.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaIII. post epiphania. domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Cum autem descendisset.. Matheus se eadiga godspellere.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaIIII. Be þere halgan clænnesse.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Ure hælend crist cydde.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The preface to Sigefyrð in the margin of fol. 17v in Joscelyn's hand is copied from BL, Cotton, Vespesian D.xiv, Item 4.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. Va. et quando uolueris be heofonwarum ˥ beo helwarum.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Men þa leofestan ute gehyran hér godes word.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The homily is for the third Sunday after Epiphany in CCCC 302.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaVI et quando uolueris. Larspel be urum drihtne.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Men þa leofestan ure drihten ælmihtig god ús singalice menegað.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The homily is for the fourth Sunday after Epiphany in CCCC 302.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaVII. aud [sic] quando uolueris de uerbis domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Men þa leofestan utan geþencan georne ˥ on úre geþance þæt fæste healdan. hu sanctus iacobus cristes þegn sǽde. hu se hælend.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The homily is for the fifth Sunday after Epiphany in CCCC 302.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. in septugesima [sic].

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Drihten sǽde þis bíspel his leorningcnihtum.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): De alleluia

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: We willað eow secgan be ðissere andweardan tide.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica in sexagesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Cum turba plurima....On sumere tíde þa þa micel mænigu.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. in quinquagesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Assumsit iesus....Hér is gerǽd.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: þæt eal folc cweðe be ús. (Ends imperfectly, Thorpe 1844-46, 164/29)

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (Begins imperfectly) ne scéotan. forþan þe hé ascunode.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria secunda.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Men þa leofestan eow eallum is cuð.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The title Euuangelium at fol. 58v and the words following it 'Cum uenerit filius hominis in magestate sua. et omnes angeli cum eo. tunc sedebit super magestatis sue. et congregabunter omnes gentes; et reliqua; Ðæt is on engliscre spræce' are not in the printed edition. They occur after '˥ þus cwæð' (Thorpe 1844-46, 106/23).

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. II. in quadragesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Egressus inde iesus.... Ðrihten hælend þréade.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaIII. in quadragesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Erat iesus eiciens.. On þære mæran tíde.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): DominicaIIII. in quadragesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Abíít iesus.... Se hælend ferde ofer þa galileiscan sæ.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Sermo de lege dei in media quadragesimae.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Men þa leofestan we rædað nu æt godes ðenungum embe gesetnesse.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Secundus sermo de iosuę et de pungnis eius.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Moyses ˥ ááron.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Thorpe 1844-46, ii, 212, but Thorpe 1844-46 218/29 Gifernys bið-224/12 on ðam ecan life does not occur here.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): De oratione moysi in media quadragesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Æfter þam þe moyses se mæra heretoga of egipta lande

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica V in quadregesima.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Ðeos tid fram þisum andweardum dǽge'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: the heading 'Secundum iohannem' precedes the Latin text at Thorpe 226/2.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria VI ante ramos palmarum.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Collegerunt pontifices...Þæt halige godspel þe ge gehyrdon nú rǽdon'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica in die ramis palmarum.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Cristes þrowung'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: One leaf is missing between fol. 102 which ends 'his agenum' (Thorpe 206/6) and fol. 103 which begins 'rihtan geleafan' (Thorpe 206/28)

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria II de passione domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Drihtnes þrówunge'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria III (alt. to II) euangelium.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Ante sex dies pasce....Ge magon gehýran secgan be ðære árwyrðnysse þysse halgan tide'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria V In cena domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Segeð on þisum bocum be þære áwurðnesse'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Die dominica paschę resurrection‾. domini de euangelio.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Oft ge gehyrdon'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Sermo de sacrificio in die paschę.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Men þa leofestan. gelóme eów is gesǽd'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Variant readings have been added by Jocelyn and at the appropriate places the leaf,

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Alius sermo de die pasche.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Hit is swiðe gedafenlic'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Feria III in pascha ebdomada.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Gelóme ætéowde'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The title 'Euangelium' stands between the passage translated from the gospel and its exposition (Thorpe 288/11)

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. in octaua paschę.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Cum esset sero... Æfter þæs hælendes æriste'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: The passage in rhythmic prose, 'Hwær beoð wyrta blosman... þæs hwilwendlican færeldes' (fols 148v/12-150/12), is not in the printed edition. It comes after ' heafde' (Thorpe 236/22)

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica II post pascha.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Dixit iesus discipulis suis; Ego sum pastor bonus....Þis godspel þe nú geræd wæs'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Omitting the passages printed 242/7-24 (Be ðisum- bysnað) and 244/7-9 and adding at the end a long passage which occurs also in CUL Ii.4.6, CCCC 188, CCCC 302, but not in Thorpe. This passage begins 'Ge magon gehýran' (fol. 152v/21) and ends imperfectly 'swícdomes 7 sýrwun-', a leaf having been lost after fol. 159.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'útan bið geséwen'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: After 'grámlican deofles' (Nap. 60/4) the text continues 'Be þam we mágod sécgan sume soðe býsne. swa swa béda awrát...endenextan dæge ' (fols 160v/24-162/18).

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica IIII post pascha.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Uado ad eum qui me misit...Manega godspel syndon gesette'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica V post octau‾.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Sume men nyton gewis'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): De fide catholica.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Ælc cristen man'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): In die ascendionis domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Primum quidem... Lucas se godspellere ús mánode'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Dominica. post. ascensionem domini.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Cum autem uenerit paraclitus...Se hælen hér on lífe'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): In die sancto pentecosten.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Fram þam halgan easterlican dæge'

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Eodem die de euangelio.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: 'Si quis diligit me... Iohannes se godspellere þe þis godspel awrát. sǽde þæt se hǽlend'

notes.head: Note
notes.body: fol. 196v/5-24 is blank.

objectDesc.extent:
230 mm x 150 mm (dimensions of all - size of leaves).
c. 187 mm x 111 mm (dimensions of all - size of written space).
objectDesc.foliation: (As Ker 1957) fols iv + 196 + iii, foliated (i-iv), 1-196, (197-9). Previously, Quire 23 was misbound before Quire 22 and as a consequence fols 157-71 were foliated 165-71, 157-64. The manuscript was rebound in 1966 using a concertina-type binding so that each quire is effectively bound separately. 25 quires now, with Quires 12 and 13 being bound together. Folio 1 is supplied.
objectDesc.collation: Quires: Collation (as Ker 1957, and checked against the codex) of fols 2-196: 11 (fol. 2), 2-78, 88 wants 1 before fol. 51, 9-128 134, 148, 158 wants 2 after fol. 102, 16-218, 228 wants 4 after fol. 159, 23-258, 2612 wants 10-12, probably blank, after fol. 196.
objectDesc.condition: The condition of the membrane is generally very good, and often quite thick in texture. Manuscript itself is acephalous. Upper margins appear to have been closely trimmed.
objectDesc.note: Blank parchment leaves have been inserted in place of the leaves missing from Quires 8 and 22. A quire is missing after fol. 50. Ruled with a pencil on Quires 1-4 and hardpoint elsewhere for 24 long lines. Pricked prior to folding. Double bounding lines.

handDesc.summary: One main hand, although from fol. 92r onwards the script changes from insular to Caroline minuscule then returns to insular.

characters.note: a is Caroline and has a fat, angular bowl with a relatively undeveloped headstroke.

d is usually insular and is the same shape as ð but tends to have a shorter back. Caroline, straight- backed d is used in the first few lines of fol. 92r, and sporadically elsewhere. It is tagged to the left (in the manner of 'prickly script' manuscripts of the the first quarter of the twelfth century from Canterbury and Rochester).
e is relatively rounded, and often has an upward-curving extended tongue, especially at word- and line-end.

f is insular throughout the manuscript. The medial and upper cross-strokes both turn down at the end and this is the single most characteristic feature of this hand. This form of f is reminiscent of that used by the scribe of Harley 55, fols 5-13
g is Caroline, with a tail that is open but slightly flattened at the bottom. From fol. 92r onwards, the tail of Caroline g sweeps round towards the bowl in a rounded fashion.
h is Caroline up to fol. 66 and insular from fol. 66 up to fol. 92r. Caroline h is used on fol. 92, but it reverts to insular by fol. 93, with some sporadic incidences of Caroline after that.
minims have consistently formed feet that flick upwards to the right and have a tagged serif in the onset stroke. The first minim of m is often more widely set than the second and third.
r is usually insular, though Caroline r occasionally occurs (as at fol. 92r, for example).

Up to fol. 66 the top of s is quite rounded. The top is flatter in subsequent folios. High Caroline s and low insular s are used from fols 66-92r. After fol. 92r long s is employed initially and finally, together with low s and the occasional high s.
ð is of the same shape as d but with a slightly longer back. The cross-stroke is very straight, slightly angled, and balanced in length, but has a small blob or flick downwards on the right side.
þ has a quite rounded bowl.
y is always dotted and is either straight-limbed or has limbs that curve outwards slightly. The tail of straight-limbed y flicks angularly upwards to the right at the end of the tail.
ascenders are wedged or tagged to the left, and very occasionally flagged to the right. ascenders of b, h, l and þ tend to be as high as the interlinear space permits.
descenders are straight and tapering, though f and r occasionally taper very slightly to the left.
accents are pronounced and hook-shaped with a distinctive flick downwards at the end. The accents are broadly similar to those in CCCC 383.
'drihten' is abbreviated by a horizontal line indicating the omission of -en, which crosses through the ascender of h. This is also seen in CCCC 303.
The punctus is used throughout.
The positura consisting of two punctus and a comma arranged triangularly is used throughout the text up to fol. 92, then afterwards much less frequently.
From fol. 92 the punctus versus, punctus elevatus and punctus interrogativus are employed.
There are flat, medially-placed, hyphens at line-ends but, rather like the positura, these tend to cluster in specific scribal stints, or may be derived from characteristics of the exemplar.
Ligatures: There are few st ligatures and only rare ct ligatures (fol. 101r/24, for example).

decoration: Initials are metallic purple or green or both colours used together. The first letter of a sentence is filled with red and titles are in red rustic capitals (Ker 1957, p. 193). The enlarged, pen-filled initials (such as the green M at fol. 82v) have foliate terminals, and blobs at a medial point of the limbs. Angular shapes, rather like the teeth of a saw, decorate the oblique lines. These initials might be similar to those of manuscripts from Rochester and St Augustine's, Canterbury in the first half of the twelfth century.

history.origin: Unknown, but likely to be south-eastern, based on scribal and textual affiliations (for these, see Treharne 2000, and Teresi 2007, and the references therein).
history.acquisition: According to Ker 1957, the addition of a flyleaf (fol. 1) on which is written the sixteenth-century title 'Sermones anglicæ sive Saxonicæ 36' and Joscelyn's notes 'show that this was one of the manuscripts used in Archbishop Parker's circle' (p. 193). 'Sum Guiliel. Bowyer 1565' is written on fol. 2, erased but visible under ultra-violet light (transcribed in Wanley 1705, p. 239). Part of the Cotton library: Thomas Cotton's name is written on fol. 2. Acquired by the British Museum along with the rest of the Cotton collection.

admin: Manuscript described by Elaine Treharne with the assistance of Hollie Morgan, Owen Roberson and Takako Kato (2010; 2013).
